title: What is your preferred genre for music? - Quora

response.answer_text: I grew up listening to Black music pretty much exclusively (Soul, Jazz, Blues, even raised with Nigerian Hi-Life). I was a huge snob about it, too, being fairly vocal about my dislike of Rock music. Emily Fisher's answer to What was the first album you ever bought (with your own money, not given as a gift)? When I left home in 1972 as soon as I turned 17, and moved to a tiny coal mining town at 8,000 feet in the Colorado Rockies, I knew full well there would be no Black people or Jews there — the only people I knew and trusted — but my need to be in the mountains was extreme enough that I gave up my people for the necessity of altitude. Emily Fisher's answer to How important was your hometown in shaping who you are? That began my crusade of insidiously trying to broaden the musical tastes of the hippies by switching their sounds mid-acid trip, from The Grateful Dead to Coltrane. Soon I realized I had to start more gradually, with Eric Burdon, pre-War, his long trip-worthy Tobacco Road spouting, “When the acid trip is over, you’ve got to go back to Mother Booze”. Sly and the Family Stone was also an easier bridge for them, and I slowly made some headway, found they could accept Rahsaan Roland Kirk far easier than John Coltrane. Meanwhile, I was being worked on as well. A Bluegrass band from the Louisiana Bayou moved to town, and stole my heart with their fine picking and party down souls. AM Radio in the NYC area where I’d come up during the Sixties was quite broad, included pretty much every type of popular music but Country. I think it was probably the only place in the U.S. in which you couldn’t find Country music anywhere on the dial. I prided myself in my musical knowledge (of course I lied a bit about not knowing any music that wasn’t Black), and was familiar with a number of international sounds, as well, but I knew absolutely nothing about any kind of Country music, and never thought to be curious. As close to exposure to Country as we got in the NYC metropolitan area was in the very late Sixties, with the old TV variety show, Hee Haw - Wikipedia, and nobody watched that unless really high and willing to fall over furniture in an exaggerated attempt at a jig. But when the Bluegrass band from the bayou, Cornbread, moved to tiny town, they instantly became my best friends, with a speed and ease usually reserved for Black people, however unconsciously. (That’s when I first discovered how Black the Deep South is, which confused me: Emily Fisher's answer to Have you ever had a run in with the KKK?) I quickly became immersed in both Cornbread’s fine picking and their record collections. 45 years later, they’ve shown up in a couple of my answers here. I danced my ass off when Cornbread played every Thursday night at the one bar’s Boogie Night, and I began my lingering acclaim for developing varyingly fabulous disguises in order to make it past the bouncers each week, though they were specifically on the lookout for me, being that I was still 3 years too young to drink legally, and made fools of them at the end of each Thursday night, when I ripped off my disguise and took a bow. Gradually, in later life, I began listening to quite a lot of Traditional Country music. By the time NWA released Straight Outta Compton, I was living in Echo Park, with a broader variety of records and tapes than ever before, booming through the hills with the shocking-for-the-times sound system I inherited from my mother’s ODed cousin, a system I was proud of until it disintegrated in one too many earthquakes. Straight Outta Compton changed everything for me, as for some time I couldn’t stand to listen to anything else. I hadn’t felt quite like that for a decade or two, since swooning to Soul records with “the arm over,” as a kid. I didn’t yet know anyone who listened to Rap, but with my snobby eclectic tastes, that was nothing new — by then I didn’t know anyone else who listened to Country, either. There in the 80s, my listening eventually boiled down to approximately 50% Rap/50% Country, and everyone thought I was nuts, especially, eventually, those who listened to Rap but shunned Country, and the other way around. And so began my next crusade, after my decade’s earlier attempt to convert the hippies. I was out to convince the world they were wrong in thinking there was a screaming dichotomy between Country and Rap, that they both told explicit True Life stories with dramatic cultural flair and a beat. That one didn’t go over any better than Coltrane did, though later I began meeting others who were very into both Rap and Country, all 10-20 years younger than I, and mostly women. Then a life changing experience caused me to leave LA in ‘93 and move onto 2000 acres without electricity in the Sonoma Hills. Emily Fisher's answer to What is an incident that changed your life? But how to make a damn living from so deep in the wilderness, still more than a decade away from being introduced to the internet? I checked out the want ads in the local paper out of Santa Rosa (1 1/2 hours away) and found one for exotic dancing, what the fuck. I’d certainly never done or even thought about anything like that before, though by then I was well aware that James Brown had taught my dancing to look like fucking at a very young age. Emily Fisher's answer to What is the worst thing you have ever been falsely accused of? So how hard could it be? I didn’t really envision being employed doing this so much as — in a scratching off things that were never on your bucket list kind of way — I couldn’t think of one good reason not to at least go in and audition, with the required 2 “dance” pieces of my own choice. And speaking of “Choice,” did your ever hear a highly explicit woman rapper by that name out of 1990 Houston? Choice (rapper) - Wikipedia No idea what ever happened to her, as I’ve heard no music at all for many years, for various fucked reasons, but for a couple of years before leaving LA, Choice was my everything, the only woman I knew of who truly spoke her damn mind. Emily Fisher's answer to When did you find yourself unexpectedly on stage?  (Fuck Quora for turning the videos into this ugly shit — who in their right mind would click on this hideosity?) Now here’s the part where I’m sorry to say I can’t supply proper details. Some time in the early 90s, before I left LA for the wilderness, a tune came out on cassette that may have actually had Country Rap in the title, but in any case, though I can’t produce the title or artist, that’s what it was, the first I ever heard until losing my mind over Gangstagrass when I caught it on Justified 20 years later. https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=eAffMSpW8KM Yup, I did go in for an exotic dancing audition with 2 pieces of my own choice. One was to one of Choice’s most raunchy raps, and the other was that Country Rap, during which I stripped down from one pinto pony printed thing to continually lesser ones, while salaciously riding a pinto pony on a stick. That’s how devoted I was to exposing the sexiness of Country Rap with an anecdote for eternity, stripping to it for strange men in a rented room! I’m guessing, though it seems wrong to me, that my love of both traditional Country music and Hip Hop are my biggest supposed discrepancies, but my musical tastes remain all over the map. Epilogue: As part of a barricade-leaping gesture that could have gotten me arrested, in 1991 I bridged the gap to turn Dolly Parton on to Choice (while working on my own rap which sampled the opening bongos in Jolene). ————————————————————- Thanks to Aaron Ellis for the inspiration. If I’d known he lives in LA, I’d have tried to meet him when I was just there, gone out to hear some music, which I never did once...

I don’t have a preferred genre of music. I have somewhat broad tastes and many reasons for that taste. In my youth, and through my undergraduate years, I was a trained pianist and greatly enjoyed that, and still like classical music a great deal. I enjoy playing it, and I enjoy listening to it. But there is a part of me, a small part, that will always think of it a little like work. It’s just residue from my time of training. Not that I hate work and effort, quite the opposite. But music doesn’t always have to be those things. I like some metal, some harder rock, and plenty of classic rock from the 60’s. But I grew up in 90’s the era of whiny, post-modern, neo-punk grunge. And it was the thing. Green Day’s Dookie was everywhere. Soundgarden being angst-ridden and hugely popular, Nirvana’s powerful social commentary from Smells Like Teen Spirit was still powerful. And the power-pop California sound of Weezer was embedded in the culture of the well-to-do kids that I associated with. I was very much a child of the times and listened to all of it. And I hated it. To me, most of the alternative rock at the time was just that; angst-ridden, whiny crap. It felt weak, and from a young age, I’ve had a powerful aversion to personal weakness. Listening to Green Day whine about “going crazy” (I was a kid, I didn’t have the advanced sensitivity to others issues I do now) and how some girl didn’t like the lead singer. That amazing piece of shit Adam’s Song about Blink-182’s loneliness. It all bothered me, as did its effect on those around me. Everyone tried to pick up the grunge style. The hair, the horrid Jnco jeans, and the “sigh, why” attitude. Hence my early adoption and love of Rap. Real music, from people with actual problems, music about personal ambition and creating power for yourself. Here was music for someone who isn’t a whiny weakling filled with angst. Tupac’s album All Eyez On Me was an eye-opener. I was introduced to it by another student in karate, and it felt right. Now, I’ve been familiar with rap before this, going back to hearing Straight Outta Compton by NWA years after it was released. But All Eyez On Me was the shit. It had rhythm, it had beat, it had lyrics about life. It had power. It was more than California Love, as awesome as that song is. Ambitionz az a ridah was a great song, with powerful lyrics about an existence. My attitude was "fuck it", cause motherfuckers love itTo be a soldier, must maintain composure at easeThough life is complicated, only what you make it to be Could I personally identify? No, I was a privileged white-kid. But what I could identify with was powerful personal ambition and having a general “don’t fuck with me” attitude.  Diddy’s Forever was good, Victory would come later. Which was my walkout/hype song for a couple of kickboxing tournaments:  Before that, as high school began and we were at peak Blink-182, I was listening to Nas, loving Nas’s flow and ability. After I got my license in 2001, it wasn’t uncommon to hear me roll up to school blasting Hate Me Now (a song I love dearly to this day), while many others were listening to a mix of post-grunge pop-rock and pop-country. At least many others in my social circles. “You have to listen to Radiohead.” No, thank you:  That’s a great song, but all of I am… is a good to great album. Then, then came Tech N9ne. One of my personal favorites. Everready being one his most well-known albums, but there are several that are seriously good. His Worldwide Choppers and powerful Speedom are just impressive feats of lyrical ability:  Again, we have a whole album that’s good in Special Effects. Eminem murders the flow in Speedom, his ability is impressive. So speaking of Eminem, one of the most capable modern poets we have right now. Some of it brutal, some of it hateful, some of it heartfelt, it’s deep, and his ability is without question. Very well-known is his Lose Yourself. One of the most inspirational, I can do it, songs ever written. Eminem isn’t bitching about his background here, he isn’t whining about circumstances. He’s acknowledging the sweet nervousness of the pressure to perform.  I cannot grow old in Salem's lotSo here I go is my shotFeet fail me not 'cause maybe the only opportunity that I got A song about seizing opportunity and grabbing life by the balls. The last lyrics in the song are “You can do anything you set your mind to, man”. While Green Day strolls down a Boulevard of Broken Dreams. Makes me fucking sick to my stomach. But Eminem’s great songs are so many that it’s hard to list them all. Rap God, Survival, till I Collapse. So many others. This persists to this day, I still love Rap, still listen to it frequently, it’s not “black” music, not anymore. It’s strength music, personal ambition music. Personal revelation music. How can you not hear Meek Mill’s Ima Boss and not get charged up?  I listen to this as I drive back to school the first day of every semester. I listened to it before meeting clients when I was a consultant. Getting ready for a fight, rolling into the arena. On the way to somewhere like that, crank Ima Boss and I’m in the mood conquer. “Ima king, where’s my mothafucking crown” is what I want to hear before I take on a new challenge. There’s power in this music. In addition to rap and classical, and metal. I am an unrepentant jazz fanatic. Coltrane being my drug of choice. I’m at the end of day, with my girl, and things are quiet, it’s Coltrane and the other greats I’m reaching for. In a Sentimental Mood says everything that needs to be said, without saying a single word. Just listen to this track and try not to be transported:  Or Soft Lights and Sweet Music, which feels like an old jazz club. With high-quality whiskey, and dim lighting. The chill after the work, the club after the win, that’s what Soft Lights and Sweet Music feels like to me. Skill, so much skill that it’s hard to describe. Coltrane had a comparatively short career, but he crammed so much greatness into it that it boggles the mind.  It’s not just Coltrane though, as great as he is. What about Miles Davis’ and his work in Flamenco Sketches:  Kind of Blue is one of my favorite jazz albums. This is another song that is all about nighttime, the end of the day. Relaxing and thinking. Dim lights and a good book, or a tablet for math, just time with yourself of those whom you care about. There is complexity here that is gilded by the calm, which is true of all the great jazz. I could go on, Thelonious Monk, Hawkins, Parker. It’s a long and capable list of musical greats. But while rap (and certain metal) charges me up, and makes me ambitious, jazz is what calms me at the end of that effort. There is duality in this taste, but it feels right to me, that’s for sure. Thanks for taking this musical journey with me, and thanks to Emily Fisher for bringing this question to my attention with her answer and my long comment.

My main genre of music (to sum up simply) is Rock. I listen to almost all genres of rock from the 60’s to today. I personally think rock music is the perfect combination and point between all genres in almost all aspects. For me: Pop is usually too soft for me and too simple. Extreme Metal can be overbearing for me and hard to really understand and enjoy. Rap is too focused on vocals and usually doesn’t have good instrumentals (However I do like Beastie Boys and Rage Against The Machine who are both rap-rock) Electronic sounds too artificial and overproduced with not much soul in it RnB sounds kind of boring and doesn’t usually keep me interested Classical has nothing to hook me in and doesn’t really have many modern techniques, it’s essentially a more basic and more musical (as in fully focused on chord progressions and melodies over anything else) form of basically all other music. I have nothing against these genres, these are just my reasons I don’t enjoy them as much as rock. If you do enjoy these genres, that’s great and it’s good that everyone likes different things. From the 60’s (which I haven’t listened to that much of) I love The Beatles, The Rolling Stones, Pink Floyd and Led Zeppelin’s earliest stuff. From the 70’s I love Black Sabbath, Queen, The Clash, Van Halen, AC/DC and Aerosmith From the 80’s my favourites are Metallica, Guns N Roses, Red Hot Chilli Peppers (yes I know it’s surprising they started in the 80’s), Bon Jovi and INXS From the 90’s I really like Nirvana, Queens of The Stone Age, Muse, Weezer (currently my favourite band of all time), Green Day, Rage Against The Machine and Jimmy Eat World From the 2000’s the bands I like most are Arctic Monkeys, The White Stripes, The Black Keys, The Strokes, The Killers, Jet and Tenacious D And finally, my favourite bands/musicians of the 2010’s are Royal Blood, Des Rocs, Ghost, Jack White, King Gizzard and the Lizard Wizard, Greta Van Fleet, The Struts and Gary Clark Jr Also if anyone’s wondering, here is my current favourite songs of all time: Death on Two Legs (Dedicated To…) by Queen 2. Say It Ain’t So by Weezer  3. Let It Be by The Beatles  I hope some people got some good recommendations from my post or even just see why I love almost every form of rock, Good day to you all!

I grew up in a household with very diverse parents in a very diverse lifestyle. As a military kid I moved everywhere, born in Cali I got my roots from my Mexican mother who is just too cool she opened my eyes to my Mexican Culture and the culture of the 90’s scene as well as the ranchera and Banda. As a teen she was rebellious and did the things teens did, went to tons of concerts and rode around California in a van visiting cemeteries and anything else she saw that was cool. Because of her I love bands like no doubt and sublime and even some heavier stuff I can’t believe she likes ( I do too). She introduced me to country and metal. My father as of now was in the military and so we moved around a lot I missed out on a lot but learned so much from the lifestyle. I was partly raised in Cali but brought up in Hawaii where I got a real taste of jawaiian and reggae, Hawaiian soul too. I learned hula and spoke the language and played the ukulele and ipu. We then moved to Georgia and from there I spent time in Texas. I’ve lived every where long enough to appreciate all kinds of culture and music. I have a fondness for oldies from the mixtapes my dad made for my mom. And I wish I lived with the rat pack so I could see them live at the sands (I lived in Vegas too). Don’t even get me started on old school rap, I’m talking real like cube and slick rick and ice t. And you know pac and biggie. I look like a Mexican marlon Brando metalhead cowboy, if you get that. I have a couple hundred dollars worth of records sitting next to me that I play every night to sleep. I literally love and live every genre of music. Even the obscure stuff.

As a teenager I listened solely to the rock ’n’ roll, hard rock, and heavy metal of the time (1976 to 1981). When I was 16 I began playing the electric guitar, and I spent all of my time trying to learn the songs I loved by bands like Led Zeppelin, AC/DC, Ozzy era Black Sabbath, BTO, The Guess Who, Nazareth, George Thorogood, etc. Shortly after starting to learn guitar I was fortunate enough to make friends with a guy that had been playing guitar for about 5 years already, though he was a year younger than me. He taught me some blues scales and the basics of the 12-Bar Blues. He was playing a strange set of scales one day as we sat playing the guitar together. I asked him why it sounded different from what he had been showing me up to that point. He told me that he was playing Classical scales. I asked him why he would be playing Classical, since he liked the same music as I liked. He told me that, basically, Classical music was (much of) heavy metal and hard rock music played by an orchestra instead of electric guitars. I thought he was pulling my leg and I laughed at him. He assured me that he was serious. He challenged me to get a few records of Classical music and listen to it closely, while trying to imagine the music being played by electric guitars instead of cellos and violins, etc. I had never really paid any attention to Classical music before, having decided it was boring as hell. I decided I had to see if I could hear what he was telling me. I bought three records - a Bach, a Mozart, and a Tchaikovsky. One by one I played them and listened closely to the notes. I was astonished to find that my friend was absolutely correct - I could hear the similarities to the heavy metal and hard rock I was listening to at that time. This experiment started me down a road of music appreciation that would likely never have happened, or would have been greatly delayed, had I not met this friend and been encouraged to broaden my horizons. I began listening to all the old blues legends of the early 20th century, and I began to listen to jazz music. I began to listen to classical music and folk, Indian sitar music and Middle Eastern stylings. I even ventured into the old country music that had always caused me to break out into hives within one or two notes prior to this awakening, and found that I liked a lot of that music, too. I fell in love with Boogie Woogie, Do-Wop and Barber Shop Quartets, Ragtime and 1930s jazz giants like Cab Calloway, etc. I became obsessed with Buddy Holley, the entire Beatles catalogue, and all of the 60s “Hippy” music, like Bob Dylan, Joan Baez, Joni Mitchell and Simon & Garfunkel, as well as 60s rock, like Jimi Hendrix, Deep Purple and Cream. I discovered Motown, funk, and R & B, and loved it all. Today there is very little music that I do not like. I have a hard time dealing with most Hip-Hop and Rap, but there are certain tracks that I like in those genres, too. I don’t like modern country, but still listen to pre-1970 country once in a while. Other than that, anything goes. I can get into most music and enjoy it thoroughly. I am thankful that I met this friend, and I am thankful for the never-ending gifts that I get to this day as a result of that friendship and what I learned from him that day. I encourage everyone to venture outside of their usual musical preferences to see if you, too, can begin to appreciate and enjoy the rich palate that is available today. EDIT: Here’s a video of a young boy named Brendan MacFarlane that just amazed me with his natural born talent for the blues. I hope you’ll enjoy it as much as I do.

I love classic rock. Modern rock just sounds either too commercial or too similar to ’90s grunge rock, of which I am not a fan. Classic metal is good, too, provided its solo has some sort of melody (specifically the solos. If you’re going to set aside a full minute for the guitarist to impress people, it might as well add something to the song, not just be there). I like all forms of classic rock, but I really like psychedelic/acid rock (Cream, Pink Floyd, Jimi Hendrix, etc.), as well as hard rock (Van Halen, Led Zeppelin, Guns N’ Roses), and progressive rock (RUSH, Gamma, David Lee Roth in the Skyscraper years). As far as other music goes, I like blues (Clapton is God), Jazz Fusion (Jeff Beck, Miles Davis’ Bitches Brew), and reggae (taking pop song progressions and using muted hits and upstrokes to turn pop into reggae is wicked fun). As far as metal goes, Megadeth is where I draw the line (aside from early Black Sabbath, before metalcore got ridiculous). And Prince is as far as I’d ever go into pop music.

I loved many styles of music…. But Psychedelic Music & Art are very cool!  From the mid Sixties onward the mysterious world of Psychedelic Music leapt onto the Pop Music scene with an urgency and subtlety hard to clearly define. It was almost what was excluded from it determined more of what it actually was.  Bands like The Jimi Hendrix Experience, The Jefferson Airplane, The Electric Prunes. Some good, some not so. But a very cool, open vibe exsisted for awhile. It quickly passed, but the influences it brought can still be seen today if you look close enough.  The artwork of those times was AWESOME! Focused in areas such as California, Detroit, London etc. Five very famous artists, and a handful of others shaped the Psychedelic Experience with sketches, oil, and eventually Digital Airbrush, in an exciting visual landscape. You knew the music by how it looked, as much as how it sounded.  The Famous Five artists above: l-r Alton Kelly, Victor Moscoso, Rick Griffin, Wes Wilson, Stanley Mouse. And don’t think it ended there! Psychedelic Music is alive and well today! Not only in influences, but in reality too. Groups like ‘Tame Impala’, ‘Queens of the Stone Age’, and ‘A Perfect Circle’ continue to mesmerize audiences worldwide, with great new psychedelic sounds. I love Psychedelic Music!  Australia’s “Tame Impala”, and “ A Perfect Circle.”

My preference for music listening is classical music broadly conceived, running from chant up through contemporary composition including electroacoustic music, but this answer is too simple. It's better to say I prefer art music from any time or place, that is to say, music that is made just to be listened to for its own sake, and that rewards undivided attention. The boundaries are hard to draw, but for me this includes much Indian, Chinese, Arabic, and Japanese music, most classical music, most electroacoustic music, most jazz, some rock music, some country and bluegrass, some hip-hop, some electronic dance music, some New Age music, and a fair chunk of what gets labeled “ambient" or “experimental" music. Out of all this stuff, if I had to pack 500 albums for exile on a desert island, more of it would be classical music than any other style. To some extent this just reflects what I grew up with, what I played, and what I know best, but I think anyone familiar with global music history would recognize that there is really something great going on with classical music. But to go back to what I said about other styles, I think any time you find a style made by grown up people who are really dedicated to making music and who expect people to really listen to it, it's probably worth giving it a chance and seeing if you can learn to hear it. That doesn't always come naturally, but I find it's almost always worth the effort.

I have eclectic taste. I like modern jazz piano (I like the three Masters in their 70’s who are still with —Keith Jarrett, Chick Corea and Herbie Hancock); down-home blues and boogie-woogie piano (the late Gene Harris and Dr. John); mordent pop songs (whether they’re by Randy Newman or Steely Dan); and the minimalist compositions of Steve Reich. So maybe I don’t have a preferred genre. You can tell my age by the stuff I like— I grew up in the ‘60’s and ‘70’s. I sing, play piano and write lots of songs, and my live shows (with a quartet)blend all these elements into something that is my own music— my own genre. My last CD (recorded live) had 18 songs on it and they could be loosely categorized as follows—7 jazz, 7 pop, 3 blues and 1 minimalist. Lots of funny songs, but some heart-breakers, too. I’ve written a pile of instructional books on piano styles such as blues, boogie-woogie, rock, country, new-age, New Orleans, Oscar Peterson, The Beatles, Billy Joel, Elton John, Stevie Wonder, Ben Folds and classic rock. Like I say, I’m eclectic.

As of now, I chose Kraut Rock. I discovered that only recently and find so many bands who present a very interesting mix of electronic landscapes, rocking guitars and jazz influences. I can barely describe that level of fascination. Kraut Rock was not an actual genre itself early on since it was a taunt for German music given by the British over their disdain by Nazi Germany which was not Nazi Germany at that time anymore. Which makes the term even more mysterious or tedious, pending from which side you look at it. But lately the term Kraut Rock has become an accepted label or umbrella term that includes German rock music that was different from rock music from that time being. Early to mid 70s is when this “genre” spawned many bands that unfortunately only existed a brief time. But in terms of numbers, it seems there was quite a lot going on. Like I said. This interesting mix of electronic landscapes - like done by Cluster, slapped into some nice fusion, which means rock music with loads of jazz influence. That truly created something unique for as long as it lasted. And it was only until recent years people begun to dig it up once more and appreciate it on a more global scale. some Kraut Rock bands also included influences from Indian Ragas which made it more mysterious and ominous. That means temporarily Kraut Rock is my favorite genre as I explore it as well as similar forms of music. I can say this once more broadened my taste in music.

I have quite broad tastes in music and I honestly cannot say which is my absolute favourite. And it really depends on what sort of mood I’m in at the time. I listen to a lot of extreme music (Black Metal, Death Metal, Grindcore, Hardcore Punk, experimental, noisy, electronic, dark, industrial-type music), which seems to grab my interest more than anything else at the moment. However, I also have playlists that cover other genres (Rhythm & Blues, Ska, Two-Tone, Rock & Roll, Jazz/Jazz Fusion, Classic Pop/Rock, Classical etc.), as well as playlists that are a deliberate mix of all sorts of genres, because I like odd mixings of styles. I’ve also recently created a number of nostalgia playlists that not only feature songs I heard when I was a child in the 1970s (before I became a teenager), but also theme music from some of the TV shows I watched as a kid. I go over to a friend’s house most weeks, to hang out and do some carpentry in his workshop. He’s 54 and I’m 51, so it’s fun to play these nostalgia playlists and remember all the songs and TV shows.

This is entirely opinionated. And probably nowhere near the truth. So don’t get triggered, please. Best or Favorite? The best in my opinion is definitely classical. Which is also my second favorite genre. I may be a bit biased, as I’m a classically-trained musician, but classical isn’t boring if you just take the time to try and appreciate it. It definitely isn’t something only your grandparents or the elders would listen to. There three main periods in classical. The baroque, classical and romantic, each with wonderful pieces. Most of the composers you’ve heard of are mainly in the romantic era. Chopin, Liszt, Beethoven, Mozart and many more. However, my favorite would have to be rock and roll. Just rock and roll in general. Of course, there are subgenres that I prefer, but everything about rock is great. My personal favorite main sub genres are alternative at first, hard rock second, and heavy metal third, which all three have subgenres under them too. Alternative have great bands like Linkin Park, Green Day (which I don’t actually listen to, but heard that they’re great), My Chemical Romance (no emo is not a genre you ignoramus), Three Days Grace, Evanescence, Breaking Benjamin, Nirvana, Pearl Jam, and the list of good alternative bands isn’t even completed. Heavy Metal includes bands like Metallica, Iron Maiden, Black Sabbath, Slipnot and a lot more. It’s definitely an amazing genre, which I recommend you to have a listen. Hard rock includes classics like Queen, Led Zeppelin, Guns n’ Roses, AC/DC, Aerosmith. So yeah, wow I did ramble a lot. Sorry for wasting your time lmao.

Well every song became a descendant of either the blues or doo-wop, (if you don't count the big band era) I like every genre pretty much! I love music period!!! 50’s : doo-wop,-The Platters Elvis, Chuck Berry, Buddy Holly, Little Richard, Fats Domino, Gene Vincent, Everly Brothers 60’s “girl groups”: The Supremes, The Marvelettes, The Shirelles >>>>60’s & 70’s - rock. - Beach Boys, The Beatles, Rolling Stones, British Invasion, Summer of Love, Tommy James, Mama’s & the Papa’s, Jimi Hendrix, The Doors The Guess Who, 3 Dog Night Led Zep, Deep Purple, Ted Nugent. early KISS, Aerosmith- ELO, Pink Floyd, Cheap Trick, CCR, -just to name a few<<<<< Soft rock-pop & singer/songwriters: Elton John. Bread. James Taylor, John Denver, Ambrosia, Stevie Wonder, Cat Stevens. -one hit wonders I like some of the 80’s: The Tubes, Asia, The Outfield Grunge genre : Alice’n’Chains, STP, Pearl Jam… Post-grunge - Collective Soul, Tonic..type bands Outlaw country - Waylon Jennings, Hank Jr. Willie Nelson Southern rock: Lynyrd Skynyrd, The Outlaws, Blackfoot, .38 Special — Jackyl Hard rock: AC/DC, TESLA, early Def Lep, early Whitesnake New hard-rock: Breaking Benjamin, Chevelle, Shinedown, etc. Those are the genres I listen to most: today's music sux!!

I love both Classic rock( Beatles, Who, and 60s groups) and 80s music. I love to dance to 80s music when I'm feeling down for a little nostogic pick- me-up. Some 70s stuff too. But just mainly that 60s 70s and 80s time period. I like some Classic stuff like Opera and Bach and Mozzart too but they are not what I usually turn to when I'm down. I listen to music I can more personally relate to when I need that wake up don't sleep in all day the world is a beautiful place— so say John Paul George and Ringo.

This is a problem for me, I liked too many. I like 50’s, 60’s pop, rock & psychedelic & 1 hit wonders. Loved the 70’s rock, late 60’s everything from Doors, Hendrix, Stones , 60’s R&B(went to high school mostly afro-American, Jewish & some Caucasian. So roots in Motown, as stated R&B. Hit jazz in 70’s following traditional & Jazz fusion. Loved the 80’s & yes Disco at times as well as Punk, missed heavy metal except a few major bands( like it just too much I like). Liked grunge & then pretty much stopped. Then got deep, really deep into Blues at this stage of life-I know that’s not 1 genre-I can’t pick just one-if I had to live on an island, I guess Motown & R&an-my best Friend was afro American & second best Jewish-I am neither & it would be hard to find a racist (hate word) bone in my body

I don’t know if there is a ‘best’ one for me. I’m more interested in the field of musical potential and how people’s different personalities influence that field in unique ways, which in turn influence the emotions of the listener. Just like there is a field of potential in everyday life, in which people are continually collapsing limitless potentials into particular outcomes, the same can be said of musicians and the sound spectrum. I’m fascinated by silence (or empty space) and how a particular disturbance can cause that silence to change into a kind of creature that can be heard with the ears, seen in the imagination and felt with the heart. Every sound creation reflects the soul of the artist. Just as an aside, try to find silence. It’s a rare thing in this world and becoming rarer by the day. I predict that in years to come, people will place a higher value on silence than they will on sound. We already have aural overload in many places in the world today. Sorry, that turned out more philosophical than I expected, but there you go …

Metal. While I do listen to other genres, metal is something unique. It’s not just growling, screaming, heavily distorted guitars and blast beats. Metal offers a variety of styles, varying from its first sounds from Black Sabbath and the like to thrash, progressive, death, black, symphonic and other sub-genres. I’ve been listening to metal ever since I first heard Alter Bridge’s and Metallica’s Blackbird and Death Magnetic albums respectively. That was about nine years ago and I haven’t looked back since.

The OCD-sufferer in me wants to cheat and say “College Radio” and be done with it. And while entirely true that nearly all my music needs can still be met by most decent college stations, I’ve taken this gruesome challenge to heart. So. I’ve given myself the imaginary parameters that I’d be stranded on a desert island with no hope for airwaves or internet radio reception and a scant 10 albums in a particular genre: I choose Art Punk. If I’m going to be stranded with a mere 10 albums, I’m 100% taking Devo, The Fall, Gang of Four, Richard Hell & The Voidoids, The Raincoats, Talking Heads, Patti Smith, Television, Wire and XTC with me.

I don't have one but Punk, Jazz, anything with a groove or somewhat experimental feature a lot but … Why settle for one type of chocolate when you can eat the whole box?Why only eat Apple pie when you can eat other desserts?Why only watch whodunits on TV?And why watch only TV?There's so much to chose from and accessiblty couldn't be easier nowadays. Music is the memory of youth for many but life also gives plenty of time for a journey of music exploration too. As l get older the percentage of Classical music l listen to has also increased, life's troubles and joys have been soundtracked already by the greats of the past and always assist with those “time standing still” moments of the present.

The music of Bach, Mozart, Beethoven all the way to Bartok & Stravinsky. And LOVE Richard Wagner POWER MUSIC! What WE call ‘classical music’. And call me ‘SNOBISH’ if you wish, BUT I feel SORRY for people who simply ‘ignore’ this music, don’t ‘listen to it’ or just ‘hate it’ [among Rock music fans, & also country music fans, we got PLENTY]. Of course, I do like Jazz, folk music, dizzie Band music & tango. But 99% of my time is CLASSICAL MUSIC of ths kind. And I HATE most Rock music, especially punk,[I still ‘think’ it makes people ‘stupid’, no shame to say this] & hip hop.

I’m a classical person. I deeply resonate with Bach and Beethoven, Strauss and Saint-Saens. I so easily feel every note of the music touching the innermost corner of my heart, lightening the dark places, smoothing the wrinkles, calming the storms. There’s a song to suit every mood I’m in, from happy dances to melancholy moans.. to cheer me when I’m bored, to sympathize with me when I’m sad or angry. There’s nothing more beautiful than the sound of a violin. So achingly sweet, so lovingly pure.. I could listen forever. I could never tire. I could always walk taller. I could always be better. Classical music inspires me to be what I am not. It brings out the talkative extrovert and urges my voice to bubble forth into song, echoing off distant walls and bouncing into vistas of untold joy. Classical music also inspires me to be what I am. It soothes me into dreaminess, coaxes forth more and more love from my heart until I could almost burst with the beauty of it all. It’s so deeply fulfilling.

I’m noticing more and more that it’s not genre that appeals to me, but certain production points. For example, I recently visited a high school favourite of mine - The Flaming Lips ‘Do You Realize’ - an absolutely gorgeous song. Listening back, I kind of didn’t like it - not enough mids & low end for my taste. The notes and words are beautiful but the recording just doesn’t catch me anymore. Weird huh? I guess this is the consequence of becoming a sound engineer.

Mine varies with mood, or who i'm with. If i'm alone, and sad (which is most of the time) i'm enjoy classic and progressive rock. When i'm in a neutral mood I go for Jazzy Ballads, Slow Swing, or dark sounding classical music. When i'm in a good mood, i'll go for metal or old school hip hop. And at random times i'll listen to soul and R&B. All of it's good, and there's hardly any bad music, it just depends to ones mood and tastes.
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Joshua Daniel Schardt

response.answer_text: I prefer metal over anything else. I've heard a fair amount of metal my whole life but it's only stuck to me properly the last year (I'm 13) I find it soothing to listen to particularly aggravated musicians, but also the beautiful melodies some bands create. I love the creativity of it all- especially just looking at some prog metal But I like alot of genres. Country I quite like, it's got the traditional drum and guitar setup I respect. I generally don't like (alongside many others) music that's mainly based on computers, but I have a soft spot for rap. It's more respectable, being so focused on vocals

I find myself listening to hip-hop/rap most of the time. Lyricism, beats, vibe, all of that I absolutely love. Artists such as Kendrick Lamar, Nas, Logic, and even Drake, to name a few. I do enjoy listening to instrumentals and subgenres that branch out or are inspired by/similar to that same genre. Bits of production by MF Doom, Madlib, Kanye West, 6ix; tracks tagged jazzhop, lofi; and whatever else have you. In constrast, there here are quite a few classical- and romantic-era pieces that I do enjoy as well; Tchaikovsky and Richard Wagner’s works, for example. And who am I to say I don’t enjoy my fair share of funky, groovy stuff as well, from old-but-gold tracks you’d imagine being featured on GOTG’s next soundtrack, to Bruno Mars’ latest chart-topper?

If you had asked me that question when I was about 10, I only liked “classical” music and more particularly that which was piano oriented, because I was a budding pianist. As my knowledge grew, my tastes started to encompass symphonic music and later chamber, though I was a latecomer to Opera. More latterly I have come to appreciate other genres such as (selective) Jazz and (selective) popular. I’m afraid that “rap” does nothing for me whatsoever, and I would still have to say that the broadly “classical” spectrum is my vastly preferred medium. However, that is largely reflective, no doubt, of my classical upbringing, subsequent conservatoire training and ensuing career.

Country It was introduced to me about a year ago, and at the time I was looking for much needed change in my life. I don’t know what it means if this genre is the best for me since I listen to anything. However, I listen to Country in the car going to work, to the gym, and random weekend trips. =) Although I am into what’s hot in Nashville, I was looking into the history of Country music and found a few I naturally gravitate to: -Blue Grass. Think acoustics with folk. -Americana. Born from classic Country, the polish viable sound heard now on the radio. -Country Rock. Rhythm and blues Country just like The Beatles.

I prefer indie rock, but personally I think all of the music genres are great. for example if you take a look upon my playlists, you will find all kinds of music there. one minute i am in the mood for classics and the next I’ll play some hiphop and after that a cheesy pop song!don’t limit your options to just one genre, try to listen all good musics, even if you don’t like them yet! because music is the light of our life and you need to get as much as possible! but mainly I find indie pop and rock more interesting than the others. LOL

When I feel like I want to listen to music, I usually prefer soft and non instrumental music. For me, the calm background of the music helps me in comforting myself (and I am sure it will help you in the same way). Usually people prefer instrumental music if their purpose is just to soothen themselves. But I do vote against that. When I usually listen to songs of familiar languages, the lyrics goes deep inside, and I really like the feel that arises. But one should always treat their heart and brain as the first preference.

When I feel like I want to listen to music, I usually prefer soft and non instrumental music. For me, the calm background of the music helps me in comforting myself (and I am sure it will help you in the same way). Usually people prefer instrumental music if their purpose is just to soothen themselves. But I do vote against that. When I usually listen to songs of familiar languages, the lyrics goes deep inside, and I really like the feel that arises. But one should always treat their heart and brain as the first preference.

I don't really have a preference as i listen to loads of different types all the time. If i had to narrow it down id have to say Rap or Electro. And no wack lil xans rap either, proper hip hop like Denzel curry, Royce da 5 9, Kanye, Cudi, J.I.D. Electro wise, things like aphex twin, burial, moderat, apparat, Drum n bass artist. I listen to everything.

I mostly like romantic songs which were sung by my favorite singer, but away from that i also listen that songs which sets to my mood. Actually all types of songs are good and i also like to listen rap songs, and rock songs. Moreover, i use to listen all genre songs. And also like to listen retro songs which are very easy to learn and remember.

Overall, probably rock. I tend to get the most done and am the most motivated by rock music. Some new, some older, it all seems to jive with my soul better. I can do well with classical as long as it is upbeat (the slower, easy going classical is good to help me sleep.) The one genre I can’t listen to is country, I don’t know what it is about country, but it doesn’t sound good to my ears - probably all the rock and roll I’ve listened to over the years.

As I have written before on Q it depends on what I am doing and what mood I am in while doing it. Generally, when I am driving in heavy traffic I prefer classical for its calming effect on me. When I’m cleaning my pad I like classic rock. When I just want to listen, for the sake of listening, it’s jazz. When I’m in a dancin’ mood I prefer Latin. When I’m drivin’ through the hood I turn up Snoop Dogg REALLY LOUD. Know what I’m sayin’? And, lastly, when my testosterone levels fall dramatically I prefer country.

Interesting question. I had older brothers who listened to a lot of folk music, so I have always liked that. Later it was a lot of progressive rock. Today, I prefer a kind of mix of the two. I like music with a good melody, lyrics that tell a good story, a singer who can make me understand what he was feeling, and flawless musicianship. So, I prefer not to put a label on it, but I guess Americana come closest. On the other hand, Mark Knopfler is my favorite artist, and he is British.

Classic Rock. The boundaries were being pushed. You had Zeppelin, The Who, Pink Floyd, Chicago, Joe Cocker, Bad Company. Bands didnt sound the same. The feel of those bands were different. So much soul in the music. For me, the Blues run a close second with the late great Gary Moore, Robin Tower, Pat Travers, Robin Trout, Kenny Wayne Sheppard, I like music that grooves and has,soul.

I prefer all genres of music! But my preferred genre of music oscillates along with my mood. So as for right now, I'll go with Hip hop (Drake or Migos), classical music (Frederic Chopin or Robert Schumann) and Kpop (NCT 127 or NCT DREAM). : ) -L

I don’t have a favorite genre persay. I like all different types of music. I just LOVE music in general. Music is my everything!!!! Now, if I were asked what my favorite band and/or musician was, I’d have to say, hands down no question about it Blue October/Justin Furstenfeld!  My soul is literally aching right now that not 1 other single person mentioned Blue October in all the rock/alternative bands that were listed!  My feelings are just so super hurt for Justin, Ryan, Jeremy, Matt and Will!!  Don't worry y’all, I will apologize for you when I see them in October.

I prefer old pop. Spandau Ballet, Nik Kershaw, George Michael, Madonna, a-ha, Cyndi Lauper, Phil Collins, Scorpions, Michael Jackson, Queen, Roxette, Simply Red, Kool & The Gang, and more. My favourite is Rick Astley. I also prefer rock. Linkin Park, Breaking Benjamin, Green Day, Three Days Grace are the best. Besides, I love instrumental classical.

Good music transcends genre boundaries. If it’s well done, I like it. That said, my CD collection leans toward jazz, classical and classic rock, with a heavy emphasis on piano/keyboards (I’ve been a pianist all my life). But I am also a certifiable Gershwin freak, am nutty for West Side Story, and I used to sing in an a cappella group (Sam Robson is un-freakin-believable). So I can get into any of those types of music when the urge strikes me. At the end of the day, if its good quality, music is music.

Well, genre, Pop (or Hot 100 if that’s considered a genre). But I mainly listen to certain artists/bands like Fifth Harmony, Camila Cabello, Little Mix, Ariana Grande, and Billie Eilish. I do however also enjoy Rap (not mumble rap though), R&B, Hip Hop, Indie Rock, Electronic, and Punk Rock.

To be honest, not one genre is a preferred one, I have a very eclectic taste but I can tell you what I don't like Drum and bass Trance Techno Garage and others in that field. My all-time favourite artist is Gary Numan.

indie-rock. i was really into mainstream pop and edm until even a year ago, but i really dislike it now. i really enjoy this genre of music because i find it authentic and heartfelt. songs that sound they're being sung straight from the heart, and not on a mic in a studio. songs whose lyrics actually make you feel so much. a good place to start is with bright eyes or keaton henson.

Rap, but not that stupid ass mumble about shit I don’t do and don’t know kinda rap. People like Witt Lowery and sim world who have lyrical skill and use their own stories to give other people going through similar experiences to help them feel like they aren’t alone. Another good artest in that same genre is Lucicious.

Since I first put on Black Sabbath’s Master of Reality at age 8, I’ve been a metalhead. That bludgeoning wall of guitar sent my pulse racing and what few hormones I had raging. As I got older my quest for all things hard n’ heavy only got stronger. And so did my pulse and my hormones. I like all kinds of other stuff too, but metal is always welcome in Bill’s eardrums!

I prefer most genre of heavy rock/metal. Most rap and pop sound like garbage to me and the emotion in most pop music isn’t there like it is in rock and metal. This is mostly due to the music and lyrics being written by a team instead of the performer. Pop performers are not artists they are overpaid singers. Rock and metal write lyrics music and perform which requires much more skill.

Soul music because its good for your soul. I particularly like soul music with a message like Keeper of the castle by Four Tops or Marvin Gays what's going on. Curtis Mayfield keep on keeping on. Brilliant when you combine music, a message and easy on the ear.

Pop and K-pop. May be pretty generic to people and people will disagree with me because I already understand many people don’t like pop and prefer another genre, but that’s just me hahahaha. -Evelyn Medrano ;)

It really depends on my mood, or the mood I want to be in. For example, if I’m going into work mode, I’ll put on some upbeat music. If I’m coming home from school, or want to get in a calm mood, I’ll listen to Minnie Riperton, The 1975 , or even Alec Benjamin. It depends on the vibe of the songs.

Genres of music I prefer: • Alternative Rock • Electropop • R&B • Hip Hop • Electric Dance Music • Indie Pop Artists I like: Billie Eilish, blackbear, EDEN, Lauv, NF, XYLØ, Sasha Sloan, Coldplay, Gryffin, Imagine Dragons, Jeremy Zucker, Charlotte Lawrence

Mozart to Metallica. The only thing that I do not like is the hardcore stuff that needs to be rated XXX for violence and what nots. To me that is not my type of music. Really it depends in my mood as to what I will listen to. I told you before my genre range is wide.

Depends on what I am doing. If I want to think, I listen classic music or some jazz/blues. (Eric Gale) If I want to exercise, I listen rap and post-rock which I love while driving. (God is an Astronaut & Mogwai) All the other genres, on YouTube when I want to watch music videos. (Vaporwave, indie rock, future funk, Edm, 50’s to 90’s music) Cursed pic kinda real8ed.
K-pop BTS is my fave band

Progressive rock and metal, for sure. There are days when I venture away and listen to something different, but I always come back to bands like Porcupine Tree, Opeth, and all of Devin Townsend’s work.

The Beatles, Led Zepplin, Pink Floyd, The Who, The Rolling Stones, Neil Young, Elton John, The Carpenters, Cat Stevens, James Taylor, Bob Dylan, Carly Simon, Billy Joel, and all melodic music!!. Melody is the key for me! too many more to name here but you’ve got the idea!
I don’t have a preferred genre. I like all genres, but I’m very picky about what I like in each genre. For instance, I like Les Thugs, but I don’t like Nirvana.
I listen and like many genre of music. But I think Electronic and progressive house are my two favouritea. I also like all kinds of rock music.

Its totally up to my mood..if im happy i go for new genre rock music if I'm sad i go for slow sad songs so its totally up to ur day and mood..sometimes i want to feel the music or other times i go for lyrics..yeah its like that

Gothic rock, dark wave, death rock, new wave, post punk, industrial, dark electro, black metal, nu metal, doom metal, gothic metal, thrash metal, grunge, punk, reggae. It’s a pity that traditional goth music has pretty much died out, but metal is nice too.

hello Alex. my interest primarily is jazz. i love jazz piano. the ones who incorporate all of the advanced jazz concepts and lend musicality to a composition are the ones i love to listen to. i also love jazz trumpet and flute. thanks.

I’m a metalhead:’) I listen almost to any kind of Metal, For example (Thrash, Groove, Melodeath, Death, Symphonic, Power, Black, Industrial, Nu, Progressive, Alternative, Viking, Technical and many others actually..)
Hard Rock because the energy of the music gets me feeling upbeat and helps soothe my aggression.I would think a lot of people feel this way.
I love almost anything country. Recently I've been exploring the subgenres country, such as southern rock, bluegrass, and red dirt country
Rap! Especially rap from The Netherlands! (Holland) I don’t understand it, but I like the language! What do you think about it?
Like Christina V. Overshank's. Like electronic mixed with some depressing House/EDM… I listen to a lot of stuff while playing video games so… yeah.

Be Alright - - Dean Lewis  Sweet - - Cigarettes After Sex  Everglow - -Coldplay  If I Go, I'm Goin - - Gregory Alan Isakov  No Right To Love - - Rhys Lewis  King - - Lauren Aquilina  I'm Not Yours - - Angus & Julia Stone  Why Can’t I Have You - - Gloria Laing  If You Go Away -- Helen Merrill & Stan Getz  She's A Rainbow - - Lola Marsh  Hurt - - Johnny Cash  The Hardest Part - - Nina Nesbitt
My music preference range is quite wide. From Vocaloid to Japanese Metal to EDM to Jazz, I’ll listen to virtually anything (except Dangdut. I HATE dangdut)

80s hair metal and heavy metal like Ratt, Cinderella, Motley, Ozzy, Judas Priest, Van Halen, Great white, Dokken, AC/DC, Twisted sister, LA Guns, Guns n Roses, Poison, Warrant, Winger, Def Leppard, and many many many more I cant explain how cool they are
I do not really have a music preference. So far as it gets my head bopping and ne feeling great, it is enough for me.
I’m a HUGE classical music fan. I like it more than other genres because it has the ability to express So many different moods and thoughts
Kpop!! Im definitely a fan!! BuddyBlinkIGot7CarotNctzenBts, (G)i-dle, WJSN, Dreamcatcher and many many many more!!!!
My genre would be, “correct me if I misplaced the meaning of the word genre" it would be Girl Bands. All the way..
Very hard to pin down to one. Classic rock and “New Wave” I guess would be the top two. New Wave as in B52’s, Talking Heads, Wall of Voodoo, Echo and the Bunnymen, and so on.
I will say my preferred genre for music is R&B, HIPHOP, Kpop, korean ballads.
I refer you to Mike Bourke's answer to Do you still buy music (CD, vinyl, digital)? What is your preferred genre? …
I like and pull from virtually every genre. I’m not at all a fan of radio edits.
Chiptunes (if they are considered a music genre) and orchestral video game soundtracks (such as the Halo theme, or “Gusty Garden Galaxy” from Super Mario Galaxy).
I like most genres of classical and popular music, Jazz, Blues, Bluegrass, you name it. What I don’t care for is mediocre music in ANY genre.
BLUES AND ALTERNATIVE ROCK. ACTUALLY I LIKE ALL GENRES BUT POP AND RAP.
Hard Rock/Active Rock favorite bands include: Skillet, Red, Greenday, Nirvana, Metallica, Scorpions, My Chemical Romance
Hip hop and pop and rock I like a lot of different types
I grew up listening to R&B / Funk back in the 70’s that was true music
UK grimm, hip hop , old skool garage, rap , bangra remixes, Indian remixes, bangali remixes, smoth jazz , r.n.b ,
I don’t know I listen to a lot of rap and country
Hard to pick one electronic vs rock n roll
A2A Rock in it’s various iterations: especially 90s.
Jazz 60's-'70's pop and R&B Classical music
Any Asian pop, hip hop & R&B
Slow jam R&Bslow jam gospelslow jam gospel whorship song
I'm a jazz pianist. What do you think?
Melody is best genre as it makes mind to feel calm and happy
